content:
You mention Pop but did not say what server settings you are currently using. This is what is stipulated by Shaw.

  • Server Type: POP
  • Incoming Server name: pop.shaw.ca
  • Port: 995
  • Username = Full email address
  • Security Connection: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password

Password is the same as used to access webmail

Post image showing you have correct server settings OR Help > Troubleshooting Information - scroll down to 'Mail and News Accounts' - copy all the data and paste it into this forum question. Some people have said they have correct settings but I've sometimes found typos, erroneuous spaces and full stops etc.

You do not mention what, if any, error message appears. When you click on 'Get Messages' are you getting an error message ? If yes, what does it say Word for Word verbatim - or just upload an image of error message. That may assist.

There maybe a logjam caused by one or more emails on server. Logon to webmail account via a browser. Is the webmail account still receiving new mail? Does the 'Inbox' have emails you cannot download ? Are there emails in the server 'Spam/Junk' folder? If yes :

  • Empty the Junk
  • In Inbox - Look for the oldest email that did not get downloaded to Thunderbird.
  • Read it and either delete if not that important or move to another server folder. Get it out of the Inbox.
  • Then in Thunderbird try 'Get Messages' to see if moving that email out of inbox gets things moving again.

I know that sometimes it seems safe to delete the compatibility.ini file in an old profile and set that profile as the default, but I don't know when it is safe and when it is not. Should simoncharlestomsett copy mbox files from the old profile that is still in the profiles folder to the new profile?
creator: mozilla98

content: My experience is all I can go on. Going from a recent release to the newest release causes no incompatibilities. Going backwards sometimes works, but only with compatibility.ini file deleted. Thunderbird's rejection of current profile doesn't mean a problem; it just sometimes starts fresh. That can be frustrating because it leaves user wondering about lost messages and contact list. My preference is to restore the old profile, after first verifying that it is complete. That eliminates the issue of missing folders. Copying mbox files always works, but can be messy with POP accounts, as it can impact the 'last message downloaded' status.

content:
Let's start again. If you are copying an old working profile to a new computer then there is no need to create a new mail account if it already exists on old computer.

I'm assuming you have got the download from the official Thunderbird website: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ So all profiles will be in the default location.

On Old computer Do you have everything ? Do you want to see exactly the same on new computer ? If yes: Then do this:

On Old computer:

  • Exit Thunderbird - this is important.
  • Access profile by doing the following: - see image below as a guide - note it it's too small then in this forum question click on the thumbnail image to see it much larger.
  • In windows search type: %Appdata%
  • Select %Appdata% file folder
  • Select 'Roaming'
  • Copy the 'Thunderbird' folder to external drive.


On New computer:

  • Exit Thunderbird - this is important.

Firewall

  • Access the Firewall which might be the default supplied with OS or controlled by an Anti-Virus you installed.
  • Make sure the Thunderbird program is set up as allowed.

Now to get Thunderbird profile info copied over.

  • Access profile by doing the following: - see image below as a guide - note if image is too small then in this forum question click on the thumbnail image to see it much larger.
  • In windows search type: %Appdata%
  • Select %Appdata% file folder
  • Select 'Roaming'
  • Delete the 'Thunderbird' folder
  • Paste the copied 'Thunderbird' folder from the external drive into the 'Roaming' folder

Thus replacing the 'Thunderbird folder with a copy of what exists on old computer.

Start Thunderbird

David.

content:
Hi grasscarpet,

What do you mean by "from a software program"? Are you using Thunderbird? What do you mean by "through Mozilla"? Mail does not go through Mozilla.

The message indicates that a server at an e-mail service provider rejected the message because it seemed to be spam. I cannot tell from the information provided if the server was your provider's outgoing server or the intended recipient's provider's incoming server.

In any case, this problem does not have to do with Thunderbird.

You may want to do some research to learn about the characteristics of e-mail messages that are detected as spam so you can avoid them.
creator: mozilla98

content:
Is the gmail account a POP or IMAP mail account ?

If POP: Gmail is known be awkward and reduce - even stop downloading if you use Pop because it cannot put deleted items in the server Trash folder. It basically wants you to logon to webmail and reduce the amount stored on server.

To Fix: Logon to webmail account via a browser and check both 'Inbox' and 'All Mail' folders. Delete a load of old mails. In 'All Mail' anything with no labels is considered archived. If you deleted email in a Pop account then only label gets removed. Emails are still on the server.

If IMAP: When you click on 'Get Messages' do you get any error message ? If yes, upload an image of the error message OR type the error Word for Word verbatim as it might assist. Does it prompt for password but it does not accept password ?

What server settings are you using ? Either upload images showing:

  • Account Settings > Server Settings
  • Need to see everything above 'Check for new messages'
  • from Server type to Authentication Method
  • Also the outgoing SMTP settings

OR

  • click on 'Help > Troubleshooting Information'
  • scroll down to 'Mail and News Accounts' section
  • Copy all the data and paste it into this forum question.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Info shows 3 gmail accounts - accounts 3,5 & 8 - all Pop. Settings look ok. Do you have 3 gmail accounts ?

Via Webmail - Did you access all of those different gmail accounts and delete from the 'All Mail' folder and then empty the Trash and the Junk ?

Gmail may deem that 24000 is still alot to leave in 'All Mail' gmail when using Pop because you have your own separate copy and do not synchronise with server folders.

Gmail have a limit on storage and they do stop downloading etc if that quota is used. Quota is not just emails, it can be photos etc. https://support.google.com/mail/answer/9312312

Check for a logjam In webmail account, look for the oldest but not downloaded to pop email and either read and delete or move to another server folder - get it out of the Inbox. Then in Thunderbird, select gmail account name folder and click on 'Get Messages' to see if that problem email on server caused things to get blocked.

content:
Hi uw,

The problem seems to be with DNS records at gmx.net, not with your server settings. What is the whole error message that you get? Would you please post a screen image of it?

Is your Thunderbird version really 15.0? Or 115.0? Either way, you may want to update.

Which client e-mail app are you using on your phone?

Your outgoing server settings match what I found on the Web. You could also try port 587 with STARTTLS. I don't expect that to make a difference.

I believe that you must talk with the gmx people.

content:
Image looks like you use a Pop account Looks like you are using some old server settings as graceba is WOW WOW uses the following:

The Incoming Mail Server for POP3 is

  • Server name: pop3.mail.wowway.com
  • Port: 110
  • Connection Security: None
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username = full email address
  • Password - same as used to access webmail account.


The Outgoing SMTP

  • server name: smtp.mail.wowway.com

OR If the email application will be accessed outside of the WOW! network, the Outgoing Mail Server should be set to

  • server name :smtpauh.mail.wowway.com
  • Port: 587
  • Connection Security: None
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username = full email address
  • Password - same as used to access webmail account.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
It's possible you are trying to connect too frequently. If you are getting auto connects that frequently then is there a reason you keep clicking on 'Get Messages' ? I only use 'Get Messages' if I'm expecting something urgently or performing a load of tests. Otherwise my auto check uses anything between 10mins and 30mins. All set for different times with odd minutes as well so the odds on a clash are minimal.

it's also possible you have an Anti-Virus which keeps scanning any file that gets opened which interupts the connection. You could access your Anti-Virus and set it up to not scan your 'Thunderbird' profile folder.

Start by setting the auto check to different times for each account. I'm not sure how many emails you expect to get in less than 10 minutes. Many servers do use Push if IDLE is available, so you would get a notification. eg: 10 mins 13 mins 16 mins 21 mins 29 mins

As I said, perhaps only annoying and not a critical issue.
creator: sage7

content:
There are many reasons for a fail. That pop up request - where it says 'Enter New Password' - you can only use that option if you have already logged onto the webmail account and updated/modified the current password.

All Passwords can only be modified via their respective webmail accounts. Then you update the stored password in Thunderbird to match the current password.

First check that your Firewall is not blocking the Thunderbird program. Firewall It might be controlled by the default supplied by OS OR it might be controlled by an Anti-Virus you installed.

  • Exit Thunderbird.
  • Access Firewall
  • Make sure the 'Thunderbird' program is set up as allowed.

Do not just disable Firewall as that proves nothing is not desirable.

  • Confirm - Thunderbird program is set up as allowed.

VPN Please check your computer to see if a VPN has been enabled. Many Anti-Virus products now offer VPN and in some cases it had been enabled by default. Servers generally do not like VPN because it attempts to hide your IP address and server may block access if it thinks you might be trying to hack the account. Switch off VPN.

  • Confirm you have checked computer for a VPN - also checked your Anti-virus to see if it now offers and has enabled a VPN - VPN is switched off.

Now to check the password and third party access settings because comcast uses Xfinity.

  • Using a browser - logon to your webmail account using your password.

Do you get access to the webmail account? If yes, that proves the server is still accepting your password. If not accepting password then there should be 'forgotten password' type of text link which you use nad follow instructions to regain access - then reset password.

Whilst in the webmail account - check the third party email client settings are enabled. top-right corner, click the Gear icon, then select Settings and Click Security. You need to select the checkbox to 'allow access to my xfinity..... See image below as guide. If enabled already - try the switch it off and then switch it back on to make sure there is no glitch. Strange as it may seem, that unchecking and reselecting the checkbox did work for another person.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Hi Chris,

The process is simple. It will take a little effort if you are new to Thunderbird. Conceptually:

  1. Find your profile folder, then the local folders directory of it.
  2. Copy your mbox file into that directory.

To find your profile folder:

  1. Open Thunderbird.
  2. Help menu in the application menu or click on the ≡ button at top right then "Help" > Troubleshooting information > Profile Folder > Show in [...]
  3. Navigate to the "Mail" folder, then to the "Local Folders" folder within it. That's your destination.

Now:

  1. Close Thunderbird.
  2. Copy your mbox file to that "Local Folders" directory.
  3. Open Thunberbird and look in the Local Folders account for that folder of imported messages.

content:
Hi Chris,

Support by phone is not available.

If that same message is popping up, then you must be trying to open the file. You don't want to open the file.

Let's start by describing the current situation and go a step at a time. Please confirm or deny each of my statements/questions about what you have done.

You got a file from Google takeout. It was compressed (zipped), right? Did you unzip it?

Then you had an mbox file with a filename extension. You removed that extension, right? If you "get info" (command-I) on that file, does the window that appears show that there is an extension but it is hidden or does it show that there is no extension?

Then you copied that file into a Thunderbird profile, right?

The full path to that file should now be ~/Library/Thunderbird/Profiles/[name of preferrred profile]/Mail/Local Folders

Is that where your file is?

If you have done all these things and that is where your profile is, what have you tried to do next?
creator: mozilla98

content:
re :options of: Retry, Enter new password or cancel. I have tried using the existing password, and a new one and nothing works.

You can only use the 'Enter new password' if you have just logged on to webmail account via a browser and modified/changed your password to a new one. So you actually have a new password to enter.

Passwords can only be modified via the respective webmail account for email address. Then you update the stored password in Thunderbird.

In most cases the username is the full email address but the login failed error message mentions a short part not a full email address.

Suggest you check your Account Settings > Outgoing Server SMTP for the account to see if the Authentication Method says 'Normal Password' and Username is full email address. Check all the outgoing smtp as you should have these setting for SMTP

  • Server Name: smtp.iprimus.com.au
  • Port : 587
  • Connection Security: STARTTLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username : username@iprimus.com.au

Password would be the same as used to access webmail account.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Need more information.

What OS are you using? What version of Thunderbird are you using? Where did you get the Thunderbird program? Windows App Store, Snap, Flatpak ? Was it downloaded from the official website: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ Need info because it tell me where the profile is likely to be located.

Are you talking about an IMAP or Pop mail account ? A repair on folder does not delete emails, it repairs the *.msf index file to match what is actually stored in the * mbox file. If emails look like they disappeared then they did not exist, you were just seeing some header information.

That can occur if an Anti-Virus decides to 'fix' an mbox file - they have no idea that a mbox file can contain more than one email, so if AV nukes the mbox file, the index is not touched, but is out of synch with reality. Gneral advise, do not allow AV's to scan profile files and folders or if you do never allow a fix.

Also check the following as they can cause a block in accessing server. This needs checking before progressing to other causes.

Firewall It might be controlled by the default supplied by OS OR it might be controlled by an Anti-Virus you installed.

  • Exit Thunderbird.
  • Access Firewall
  • Make sure the 'Thunderbird' program is set up as allowed.

Do not just disable Firewall as that proves nothing is not desirable.

  • Confirm - Thunderbird program is set up as allowed.

VPN Please check your computer to see if a VPN has been enabled. Many Anti-Virus products now offer VPN and in some cases it had been enabled by default. Servers generally do not like VPN because it attempts to hide your IP address and server may block access if it thinks you might be trying to hack the account. Switch off VPN.

  • Confirm you have checked computer for a VPN - also checked your Anti-virus to see if it now offers and has enabled a VPN - VPN is switched off.

re web host provider,Hostgator, Have you recently moved to Hostgator ?

Are your emails being hosted on a Plesk or Windows server? That would effect server settings.

I presume you can logon to webmail account to see emails on server. So you know password works. Do confirm you can acess the webmail account.

It would be useful to see what you are currently using for Account SEttings > Server Settings. Easy method - upload an image file which has the username/full email address edited/blanked out. check the username is the full email address.

Good info at this link: https://www.hostgator.com/help/article/email-connection-settings

Try this: - click 'account settings' - highlight account in left side bar - now, in lower right, click the 'edit SMTP server' button - does the next screen show the email address of this new account? Or does it show the email address of a different account?

If i shows a different email address, you're using the wrong SMTP server. back up to prior screen, click the dropdown menu for 'Outgoing SMTP server' and select the one for your account.

content:
If I understand the situation correctly, every message sent to your old gmail address causes the Google mail server to report that it cannot deliver the message to your mchsi.com address. The only explanation that I can think of is that Google is trying to forward mail.

Google's instructions for turning automatic fowarding off:

  1. Open Gmail.
  2. Sign in to the account that's forwarding your emails.
  3. In the top right, click Settings See all settings.
  4. Click the Forwarding and POP/IMAP or Forwarding tab.
  5. In the "Forwarding" section, click Disable forwarding.
  6. At the bottom, click Save Changes.

Was forwarding set?

content:
If you get a message from a Google server saying that the recipient's address at mchsi.com could not be found whenever anyone tries to send a message to your "old" gmail account, then the problem has nothing to do with Thunderbird, so removing and re-adding accounts in Thunderbird will have no effect.

The question is: Why is Google trying to send messages to your old mchsi.com address?

Forwarding is the only reason that I can come up with.

If you are willing to take the time, though, let's verify your settings in Thunderbird.

Please report your incoming and outgoing server settings for that old gmail account in Thunderbird. Incoming server settings are in account settings > server settings. Outgoing server settings are in account settings > click on account name > edit SMTP server.

server name port connection security method authentication method username: just report if whether or not you are using your full e-mail address

content:
Kathy, thanks for the photos. I don't see anything that I would suggest changing, partly because I am not familiar with gmail, which I don't use. But I wonder why you use port 465 on one outgoing server and port 587 (which, I believe is more standard) on the other. I also wonder whether you should have two outgoing servers or if your two gmail accounts should use the same outgoing server. These are things that I wonder. I do not know the answers.

Your photos remind me that your "old" gmail account uses a custom domain. I am no expert on DNS records used for e-mail (though I have my own domain and have had to mess with DNS records a few times in the last 25 years), but I read that it's possible to use DNS records to forward e-mail messages to a specific address. Is it possible that you are doing that? I don't know if a failure from that process would cause a Google server to give you an error message.

So I am grasping at straws, whatever that means, but maybe the idea of DNS records provokes a useful memory or thought in your brain.
